Thousands of Salvation Army bell-ringers take to storefronts across America each holiday season.
Reporter and essayist Mike Adamick discovered that becoming one of them is not as easy as it looks.
It was my first assignment as a reporter, to stand in front of a store and beg for money.
My editor said, `Get used to it if you want to stay in this business.
Though I suspected a brass bell and a Santa costume would hardly qualify me for a Pulitzer, I had high hopes.
I had dreamed of filling the kettle in a matter of hours.
I envisioned people lining up for blocks to dump cash at my feet, saying, `You just have a way with that bell.'
A man approached the store and I rang my bell and smiled.
`I'll get you on the way out,' the man said, patting his pockets and shrugging, as if to say he was really a good guy but his jeans were simply not in the giving spirit.
Twenty minutes later, the man bolted out of the store and rummaged through his grocery bags, searching for something we both knew didn't exist.
I rang my bell loudly just for him, but he hopped into his car and sputtered away.
`Merry Christmas,' I grumbled, adding a word here and there.
The phrase `I'll get you on the way out' is the bell-ringer's lament.
One woman, though, couldn't even find it in her heart to utter that.
Hugging a frozen turkey, she stopped and contemplated the kettle.
`Well, I just don't have time for this,' she snapped.
`Foul mood?
